head.title: Repeat After Me: Bats Are Our Friends

hedline.hl1: Repeat After Me: Bats Are Our Friends

abstract.p: Letter from John R Bianchi, National Audubon Society communications director, holds Sept 29 news article about bat exterminator Jim Dreisacker reveals that in spite of facts, people still do not understand how important bats are to them

block.p: Your Sept. 29 news article about the bat exterminator Jim Dreisacker revealed that in spite of the facts, people still do not understand how important bats are to them.
Your Sept. 29 news article about the bat exterminator Jim Dreisacker revealed that in spite of the facts, people still do not understand how important bats are to them.

Wildlife does not need to justify its utility to people in order to exist. Even so, bats are among the most useful creatures, with each consuming thousands of insects every night. During this time of anxiety over insect-borne diseases, including West Nile virus, the value of bats cannot be underestimated.

Like many, I'm happy to have bats take up residence with me. The tangible benefits bats bring far outweigh any perceived risks of rabies. It is unfortunate that someone can make his living by exploiting fears and superstitions.
JOHN R. BIANCHI Communications Director National Audubon Society New York, Sept. 29, 2000
